Graphical abstract A comprehensive review to summarize the impressive works of bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z based photocatalysts and give the critical discussions on the current developments of self-adaptive regulation strategies. The bulk/surface states of semiconductor photocatalysts are imperative parameters to maneuver their performance by significantly affecting the key processes of photocatalysis including light absorption, separation of charge carrier, and surface site reaction. Recent years have witnessed the encouraging progress of self-adaptive bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z for photocatalytic applications spanning various fields. However, despite the maturity of current research, the interaction between the bulk/surface state and the performance of Bi x O y Br z has not yet been fully understood and highlighted. In this regard, a timely tutorial overview is quite urgent to summarize the most recent key progress and outline developing obstacles in this exciting area. Herein, the structural characteristics and fundamental principles of Bi x O y Br z for driving photocatalytic reaction as well as related key issues are firstly reviewed. Then, we for the first time summarized different self-adaptive engineering processes over Bi x O y Br z followed by a classification of the generation approaches towards diverse Bi x O y Br z materials. The features of different strategies, the up-to-date characterization techniques to detect bulk/surface states, and the effect of bulk/surface states on improving the photoactivity of Bi x O y Br z in expanded applications are further discussed. Finally, the present research status, challenges, and future research opportunities of self-adaptive bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z are prospected. It is anticipated that this critical review can trigger deeper investigations and attract upcoming innovative ideas on the rational design of Bi x O y Br z -based photocatalysts. Keywords Bismuth oxybromide Self-adaptive engineering Pollutant degradation Energy application Photocatalysis 1 Introduction The massive energy and environmental concerns associated with the excessive consumption of fossil fuels have inspired human beings to seek more environmentally friendly manners to conduct our daily production and life [1–3]. Currently, harvesting inexhaustible sunlight via semiconductors to target the photosynthetic or photodecomposition reactions is regarded as a fascinating approach to simultaneously solving global energy shortage and eliminating environmental pollution [4–6]. From the perspectives of long-term development and practical application, it is essential to exploit robust, stable, and cost-efficient semiconductors beyond early explored TiO2, which shows good photocatalytic performance only under ultraviolet (UV) light due to the wide band-gap [7]. As the group of V-VI-VII compounds, bismuth oxyhalide (Bi x O y X z , X = Cl, Br, I) has attracted great recognition because of the unique layered crystalline structure, visible light absorption, low toxicity, and excellent physicochemical properties [8]. Taking the typical pristine BiOX as an example, with the number of halogen atoms increasing in BiOX, the band-gap decreases from BiOCl to BiOBr and to BiOI. Therefore, among various Bi x O y X z materials, Bi x O y Br z is the most attractive one with suitable band gap width and stability to drive visible light-induced redox reactions [9]. Despite the extensive studies and great advances, the applications of pristine Bi x O y X z are primarily focused on environmental photocatalysis, and due to the finite light response and/or recombination of charge carriers, the state-of-the-art catalytic efficiencies are still unsatisfactory [10]. Furthermore, the steady electronic structure, specific surface atomic configuration, and low conduction band (CB) position of pristine Bi x O y X z further restrict its applications in specific reactions, such as N2 reduction, CO2 reduction, and H2 generation. To improve the photocatalytic activity of traditional Bi x O y X z and span its applications, several tactics including macro and micro structure regulation [11–13], co-catalyst modification [14–16], and heterojunction construction [17–20] have been adopted by researchers aiming to delay the recombination rate of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and tune their band gap structure. In nature, for the individual survival and the persistence of populations, organisms may evolve their physical parts or behaviors in response to external environment changes, which is a self-adaptive process [21]. Similarly, for nanomaterial synthesis, we can manipulate the macro and micro structure of nanomaterials by changing the synthetic environments like solvent, pH, additive, precursor temperature, reaction time, and so on [22,23]. The self-adaptive process is thermodynamics favorable, which finally creates the nanomaterial with different bulk/surface states such as crystalline, morphology, chemical composition, and surface properties [24]. Numerous engineering strategies based on self-adaptive processes have been demonstrated in the reports on Bi x O y Br z -based semiconductor photocatalysts. For example, the morphology and exposed crystal faces of the Bi x O y Br z semiconductor can be administered by adding different surfactants during the synthesis process [25–27]. The terminal surface state of Bi x O y Br z relies on the used solvent, which is readily tuned in various synthetic routes [28–30]. Changing the pH and reagents can result in disturbances of the periodic atomic arrangement of Bi x O y Br z and create diverse defective sites [31,32]. It is well-demonstrated that these different bulk/surface states show huge impacts on the performance of semiconductors since they could affect the key processes of photocatalysis including light absorption, charge carrier separation, and catalytic reaction [33]. With the deeper understanding of the self-adaptive process in recent years, our knowledge of its impacts on the photophysical and photochemical properties of Bi x O y Br z semiconductors reaches a new stage. Take defect engineering for instance, initially, defects have been considered as electron traps in Bi x O y Br z semiconductors, which may induce the charge carrier recombination and hinder the photocatalytic process [34]. However, current researches have revealed that the defective sites of Bi x O y Br z can participate in the reaction as catalytic adsorption and active sites to promote photocatalytic efficiency [35]. In addition, various types of defects have been discovered and their capabilities to enhance light harvesting, promote charge carrier separation, and even change the band alignment of Bi x O y Br z semiconductors have been recognized [36–39]. Given that the literature on self-adaptive bulk/surface engineering of Bi x O y Br z has now reached a new and exciting stage, a timely and tutorial overview is necessary to summarize the most recent key progress, developing trends, and emerging scopes. In this review, we endeavored to comprehensively overview the up-dated impressive works of bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z -based photocatalysts and give a critical insight on the current developments of self-adaptive regulation strategies. We classified the bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z into several categories, and their unique photophysical and photochemical properties are briefly analyzed. Various methods including in-situ synthesis and post-treatment methods based on self-adaptive progress for controllable synthesis of bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z , as well as their working mechanism, advantages and limitations were critically discussed. Moreover, the recent advances of bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z in diversified photocatalytic applications were summarized and the underlying reaction mechanisms as well as the key structure–property-activity relationships were revealed and clarified. We ended this review by casting the existing challenges and future opportunities, which is hoped to offer valuable direction for more rational design of Bi x O y Br z -based photocatalysts towards multifarious photocatalytic applications, consolidating the fundamental theories of self-adaptive engineering strategies, and bring new opportunities for future researches. 2 Fundamentals of Bi x O y Br z photocatalyst 2.1 Typical structure and morphology of Bi x O y Br z The microstructure and morphology (i.e., size, shape, and dimensions) of photocatalysts are key factors affecting their photocatalytic performance [40], since the modulation of these parameters will have a direct impact on the light utilization efficiency, charge carrier transport path, and surface reaction dynamics [41]. Therefore, a structural and morphological interpretation of BiOBr at the microscopic level is necessary for better understanding the fundamental of Bi x O y Br z -driven photocatalysis and working mechanism of various self-adaptive bulk/surface engineering strategies. Fig. 1 (a) shows the crystalline structure of typical pristine BiOBr as the simplest Bi x O y Br z materials. As a typical layered ternary oxyhalide, the crystal structure of BiOBr is assembled by [Bi2O2]2+ layers and Br─ layers that are connected by van der Waals force [42]. Typically, Bi and O are bound to form [Bi2O2]2+ layer by canonical covalent bonds, whereas the double-layered Br─ sheets stacked along the z-direction intercalate, thus forming the PbFCl-type structure of BiOBr [43,44]. It is worth noting that the strong intra-layer covalent bonding and weak inter-layer nonbonding (van der Waals forces) endow BiOBr with an open indirect transition crystal structure, which facilitates the rational structural design of the [Bi-O] and halogen layers [45]. The open crystal structure of BiOBr also facilitates the generation of multilayer structures of BiOBr in terms of energy and thermodynamics. At the same time, the large layer space is conducive to the polarization of atom's orbits and the generation of an internal electric field (IEF) perpendicular to the [Bi2O2]2+ layers and Br─ layers. Note that during the photocatalytic reaction process, the existence of IEF will further favor the separation of electron-hole pairs. Currently, BiOBr materials with various nanostructures have been synthesized and reported, including zero-dimensional (0D) quantum dots, one-dimensional (1D) nanorods, two-dimensional (2D) nanosheets, and three-dimensional (3D) hierarchical architectures [46]. As shown in Fig. 1(b), Han et al. reported a typical room-temperature hydrolysis strategy for progressively manipulating the morphology of BiOBr from 0D to 3D [47]. For preparing 0D BiOBr spherical quantum dots, sodium oleate was mixed with Bi(NO3)3 to form bismuth oleate in ethylene glycol (EG), which was then hydrolysis in the presence of NaBr aqueous solution. After stirring at room temperature for a while, the final product can be formed. 1D BiOBr nanorods were prepared using bismuth subsalicylate as Bi source and template simultaneously. 2D BiOBr nanosheets with different sizes and thicknesses can be regulated with different solvents such as H2O, EG, ethanol, and isopropyl alcohol. 3D BiOBr was formed with the assistant of surfactant or capping agent that can guide the self-assembly of low dimensional (e.g., 1D nanorods, 2D nanosheets) building blocks into the higher-order 3D BiOBr hierarchical architectures. Above all, it can be seen that the Bi x O y Br z materials exhibit tunable electronic states, easy manipulation of morphology, good stability and accessibility, which provides a powerful platform for modulating photocatalytic activity through bulk/surface engineering. 2.2 Fundamental understanding of Bi x O y Br z -driven photocatalysis The light absorption capacity, intrinsic photoexcitation of electron-hole pairs, charge carrier migration, and redox capacity of photocatalytic materials are usually directly related to their energy band structures including valence band (VB) position, conduction band (CB) position and band gap values [48]. Due to the special structure of BiOBr monolayers, the minimum conduction band (CBM) and the maximum valence band (VBM) of BiOBr are situated in different positions [49,50], which endows BiOBr with indirect band gap semiconductor characteristics, and the photogenerated electrons therefore belong to an indirect transition mode with sufficient light polarization space [51]. As shown in Fig. 1(c), the electronic density of states calculations for BiOBr show that the main contributing orbitals of VBM are O 2p and Br 4p states. The hybridization between Bi 6p and O 2p or Br 4p contributes to the bottom and middle of VB. On the other hand, the main contribution orbit of CBM in BiOBr is the Bi 6p orbit [52], and the upper part of CB in BiOBr is primarily composed of Br 4s orbit [53]. In addition, the Bi 6s orbital can be hybridized with the O 2p orbital and result in a high degree of dispersion in VB, thus promoting the transfer of VB photogenerated holes and inhibiting the recombination of photogenerated charge carriers. In order to better understand the photocatalytic oxidation and reduction process over Bi x O y Br z , it is necessary to interpret some basic principles. In general, the photocatalytic reaction based on Bi x O y Br z can be divided into three stages [6,54]. As shown in Fig. 1(d), firstly, when light with energy larger than the band gap of Bi x O y Br z irradiated, the electron on VB of Bi x O y Br z will leap to CB, while leaving a hole in VB. Subsequently, the presence of some defects and dangling bonds in Bi x O y Br z can capture electrons or holes and prevent them from recombining. These captured electrons and holes finally diffuse to the surface of Bi x O y Br z for further reactions. As for the photodegradation of organic pollutants, photogenerated holes, and reactive oxygen species (ROSs) such as O2 •− and •OH can oxidize the adsorbed organic pollutants into non-toxic small molecules or completely mineralized [55]. For solar fuels production, the photogenerated electrons can activate the raw materials (e.g., H2O, CO2, N2) adsorbed on the catalyst surface, forming reaction intermediates that are finally reduced to the corresponding products (e.g., H2, CO, NH3, etc.) [56,57]. In terms of photocatalytic organic synthesis reactions, the photogenerated electrons, holes or ROSs can interact with the substrates through charge transfer or energy transfer to give the final products. Therefore, to enhance the photocatalytic performance of Bi x O y Br z , it is necessary to design function-oriented engineering strategies for optimizing the three fundamental aspects of light absorption ability, charge carrier separation efficiency, and surface reaction sites. 2.3 Key issues related to Bi x O y Br z -driven photocatalysis Despite the aforementioned merits of the Bi x O y Br z photocatalyst, there are still some key issues that need to be deeply investigated to maximize the application potential of Bi x O y Br z in photocatalysis (Fig. 1d). The first issue related to Bi x O y Br z photocatalyst is the band gap structure limitations [58]. As the band alignment demonstrated in Fig. 1(c), pristine BiOBr features a high VB position with sufficient oxidation ability and is able to produce ROSs through H2O oxidization. As for the reduction ability, the CB position of pristine BiOBr is closed to zero potential at pH = 7, which hinders its applications for mainstream photocatalytic reduction reactions (e.g., H2 production by H2O splitting, CO2 reduction, N2 fixation, and some organic synthesis reactions). To improve the photocatalytic reduction capability of pristine BiOBr, adjusting the CB positions of Bi x O y Br z to be more negative to drive most photocatalytic reduction reactions is quite essential. In this regard, the introduction of defect engineering, Bi-rich strategy, and doping strategy are available to precisely tune the band gap and band-edge band positions of Bi x O y Br z . This will be further discussed in Section 3. The second key point should be the IEF strength. Although the narrow band gap of Bi x O y Br z allows for more visible light absorption, it also contributes to high photogenerated charge carrier recombination rates [59]. As a typical layered material, the IEF of Bi x O y Br z plays an important role in the separation of charge carriers by promoting charge transfer from the bulk to the surface [60]. The strength of IEF depends on the electronic properties of Bi x O y Br z , which can be tuned with heteroatoms doping strategy by introducing localized electronic states into the band gap, changing the atomic environment, and widening the static potential difference between the [Bi2O2]2+ and halogen layers. Increasing the atom ratio of Bi to Br can also achieve this goal. It is even possible to expand the crystal spacing of the material by decreasing the thickness of Bi x O y Br z , which leads to a greater difference in charge density between the flat plates, thus enhancing the strength of IEF. The last issue related to the Bi x O y Br z semiconductor concerns its surface/interface state. As mentioned above, the surface reaction is one of the critical steps for the photocatalytic reaction, which is determinedly influenced by the surface properties of the catalyst. Modifying the Bi x O y Br z surface with functional groups, selectively exposing specific crystalline planes, and introducing surface defects are able to modulate the surface/interface environment and accelerate the surface reactions. Specifically, through functional group modification and crystalline plane regulation, it is possible to improve the photocatalytic reaction rate as well as selectivity towards target products. Surface defects can serve as not only direct ligand sites for enhanced adsorption of typical molecules such as N2, O2, CO2, and H2O, but also reaction sites to activate these reactant molecules and promote their transformation. The unique layer structure of Bi x O y Br z provides a convenient platform to regulate its surface/interface state, and various surface engineering strategies have been developed by scholars, which will be disclosed in the following sections. 3 Classification of self-adaptive bulk/surface engineering strategies As mentioned above, during the photocatalytic process, the semiconductor can only absorb photons with energy at or above its band gap, upon which the electrons are excited to the CB for surface reduction reactions while the holes are left in the VB for surface oxidation reactions [61]. Since the catalytic efficiencies of pristine BiOBr are greatly limited by the finite light response and/or charge carrier recombination, various engineering strategies based on the self-adaptive process have been explored to create Bi x O y Br z with different bulk/surface states such as crystalline, crystal plane, chemical composition, and surface properties. It is generally accepted that these bulk or surface state changes could significantly impact the physicochemical properties of semiconductors, thus affecting their light absorption capacity, concentration of photogenerated charge carriers, and surface reactive sites [62–65]. Fig. 2 summarizes the impacts and strategies of various self-adaptive engineering based on Bi x O y Br z semiconductors. (i) New electronic states could be generated after the bulk/surface coordination bonds were weakened by the specific regulation methods, which can narrow the band gap or act as an intermediate state for light excitation, thus expanding the light absorption range [66]. (ii) The bulk/surface defects induced by the self-adaptive engineering may provide an alternative way for the energy relaxation and transfer of photogenerated charge carriers, thus manipulating the charge carrier dynamics [61]. (iii) The self-adaptive regulation engineering can enrich the surface reactive sites, thus promoting the adsorption and activation of reactants [67,68]. To comprehensively understand these self-adaptive bulk/surface engineering strategies and explore their roles in the photocatalytic performance of Bi x O y Br z , we divided them into six categories, including surface defect engineering, heteroatom doping, surface modification, bismuth (Bi)-rich strategy, lattice disorder, and crystal plane engineering for individual studies (Fig. 2). 3.1 Defect engineering 3.1.1 Anion vacancies There are two kinds of anionic vacancies in Bi x O y Br z semiconductors: oxygen vacancies (OVs) and bromine vacancies (BrVs). OVs are the most frequently studied vacancies that can be easily introduced, mainly because of the low energy required for the escape of lattice oxygen from the Bi x O y Br z surface [69–71]. Xie’s group prepared BiOBr-OV nanosheets with different concentrations of OVs [72]. The presence of OVs was confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and electron spin resonance spectroscopy (ESR). As shown in Fig. 3 (a), the O 1s spectrum of BiOBr-OV is significantly broadened compared to BiOBr with lattice oxygen (530.3 eV) and hydroxyl (531.9 eV) that designates the existence of adsorbed oxygen at OVs species. Meanwhile, BiOBr-OV has a distinct characteristic EPR signal at g = 2.002 (Fig. 3b), which can be ascribed to electrons trapped in OVs [73]. Density functional theory simulation (DFT) shows that after introducing OVs, a defect level formed in BiOBr-OV, leading to a strong local charge around the vacancy, which is conducive to photogenerated charge carrier separation. This could be further confirmed by time‐resolved photoluminescence spectra (TRPL), where OV-induced emission exhibits a longer lifetime (610 nm) relative to intrinsic band edge emission (430 nm) (Fig. 3c). Moreover, the light absorption range of BiOBr-OV was slightly broadened as compared with pristine BiOBr. Peng and co-workers prepared a few-layer BiOBr nanosheet containing OVs (BiOBr-Ov) [74]. From the X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) spectrum (Fig. 3d), it can be seen that after the introduction of OVs, the characteristic peak intensities of BiOBr about its crystal planes are significantly weakened, which indicates that the existence of OVs seriously affects the crystallinity of BiOBr. They also explored the role of OVs in promoting the charge carrier transfer process by different photoelectrochemical characterizations. Among them, the photocurrent intensity of BiOBr-Ov was much higher than that of BiOBr (Fig. 3e), and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) suggested that the resistance in BiOBr-Ov was smaller (Fig. 3f). These results indicate that OVs in BiOBr-Ov play an important role in enhancing the separation efficiency of photogenerated charge carriers. In addition to tuning the light absorption and charge carrier separation, Wu et al. demonstrated the capability of OVs towards adsorption and activation of reactants [75]. Typically, the BiOBr atomic layer with OVs has a smaller water contact angle than pristine BiOBr (Fig. 3g and h), which indicates that the generation of OVs endows BiOBr with better surface hydrophilicity. Additionally, the oxygen-deficient BiOBr is negatively charged, which facilitates the adsorption of CO2 on the atomic layer surface (Fig. 3i). Meanwhile, as shown in Fig. 3(j), the computational results of DFT simulations show that the presence of OVs leads to increased charge density and charge delocalization, which promotes electron transport. Li and co-workers proved that as for ultra-thin BiOBr with OVs, OVs act as the catalytic center for N2 adsorption and activation by providing local electrons for π back contribution to effectively activate adsorbed N2 (Fig. 3k) [76]. In contrast to the “gold rush” of OVs, there are few reports on the research of BrVs [77,78]. On the one hand, the formation mechanism of BrVs is more complex; on the other hand, BrVs are considered as the recombination center of photogenerated charge carriers, thus reducing the reaction performance of BiOBr. For example, Lu and co-workers demonstrated that after extraction of Br ions from BiOBr by Ag+, the BiOBr with BrVs shows decreased photoactivity as compared to the original BiOBr because of the poor separation efficiency of charge carriers [77]. Although extensive researches have been carried out on anion vacancies, especially OVs in BiOBr, there are still some problems unsolved. For example, the density of OVs is prone to decrease during the reaction process, thus resulting in reduced photoactivity and poor photostability, and the Br vacancies in BiOBr are easy to become electron trapping states which affect the separation efficiency of charge carriers. Therefore, how to engineer the anion vacancies in Bi x O y Br z to render the catalyst with both better stability and excellent activity still need more effort in future research. 3.1.2 Cation vacancies Because the formation energy of cation vacancy, i.e., Bi vacancies (BiVs) is higher than that of anion vacancy, the introduction of BiVs in Bi x O y Br z is more challenging, and only a few researches have been devoted to it. It is generally accepted that the BiVs can affect the electronic structure and physicochemical properties of Bi x O y Br z by tuning the electronic configuration and orbital hybridization [79,80]. For example, Di and co-workers employed an ionic liquid-assisted synthesis method to fabricate ultrathin BiOBr nanosheets enriched with Bi defects on the surface (VBi-BiOBr UNs) [81]. Due to the ultrathin morphology of BiOBr nanosheets, the proportion of exposed surface atoms increases, when BiVs was formed only at low atomic escape energies. The Bi atom vacancies on the surface of BiOBr nanosheets can be clearly observed from the STEM images (Fig. 4 a and b), while the XPS O 1s spectrum does not show obvious peaks caused by OVs (Fig. 4c). Furthermore, the XPS of the Bi 4f 5/2 peak for VBi-BiOBr UNs sample shows a positive shift relative to the BiOBr nanosheets (Fig. 4d), indicating the different local atomic structures around Bi atoms. Due to the introduction of surface BiVs, the light absorption edge of VBi-BiOBr extended from 430 to 500 nm compared to pristine BiOBr nanosheets, and the band gap of VBi-BiOBr decreased from 2.77 eV of pristine BiOBr nanosheets to 2.65 eV (Fig. 4e). In addition, DFT results show that the VB edge calculated density of states (DOS) of VBi-BiOBr is much higher than that of the original BiOBr nanosheet (Fig. 4f), which fully proves that BiVs can upsurge the charge density adjacent to the Fermi level, and further enhance the charge carrier transfer and separation. In another case, Zhang and co-workers implanted both BiVs and OVs into the surface of BiOBr nanospheres via an ion-exchange strategy, and prepared a hierarchical Bi2MoO6/BiOBr composite (Bi2MoO6/VBi+O–BiOBr) [82]. Due to the synergistic effect of OVs and BiVs, the resulting composite exhibits a significant change in energy band structure as compared to VO-BiOBr with only OVs (Fig. 4g). In addition, the photoluminescence (PL) spectra show that the dual vacancies acting as charge separation centers greatly hinder the recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes (Fig. 4h). They also demonstrated that the existence of surface BiVs could diminish the formation energy of OVs. The lattice oxygen of BiOBr would be easily released during anion exchange to create more OVs in the composite, as confirmed by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra (Fig. 4i). This work fully demonstrates the synergistic effect between different vacancies under certain conditions, which suggests that rationally integrating different vacancies could bring a new breakthrough in maximizing the photocatalytic performance improvement. 3.1.3 Extended defects Generally, the vacancies in semiconductors refer to point defects. However, if there are too many point defects on the surface of Bi x O y Br z , the aggregation of defect points will lead to extended defects. For extended defects, the escape of a large number of atoms on the catalyst surface will greatly change the microstructure of the catalyst, such as the surface flatness and pore structure [83,84]. Typically, Wu et al. synthesized ultrathin BiOBr nanosheets with extended defects by the solvothermal method through synchronously controlling the amount of hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) and polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) [26]. As shown in TEM images of Fig. 4(j and k), the as-prepared catalyst exhibits a nearly transparent ultrathin nanosheet morphology, and there are pits with a diameter of about 2 nm on the catalyst surface. These pits significantly increase the specific surface area of the catalyst. Moreover, because of the existence of a large number of coordinatively unsaturated pits on the surface, the band gap of engineered BiOBr was reduced from 2.75 eV for blank BiOBr to 2.68 eV, and thus the light absorption capacity was enhanced. The pit defect also acts as a trapping center of photogenerated charges and active sites for the adsorption of reactants. In addition, the ultrathin structure cooperated with the pit defects also reduced the surface resistance of the defective BiOBr nanosheets, and accelerated the migration of charge carriers to the catalyst surface (Fig. 4l). In conclusion, introducing an appropriate amount of defect into the original Bi x O y Br z is beneficial to photoactivity improvement. Note that precise control of defect density is critical, since if the defect density is too low, the as-created active sites are limited, while too many defects might result in undesired charge carrier recombination. In addition, current studies are mainly focused on the single defect, and research on the integrated and polyatomic defects in Bi x O y Br z is lacking. This is mainly because the synergistic interaction of multi-atomic vacancies is not clear. What’s more, different vacancies may adversely impact the photoactivity enhancement and stability of the semiconductors. Therefore, multiple advanced characterization techniques should be employed to explore the formation mechanism and interactions between the diverse vacancies, thus promoting the development of Bi x O y Br z with multi-vacancy synergy. 3.2 Heteroatom doping Heteroatom doping is one of the most common ways to change the crystal structure of semiconductors [85]. Currently, Bi x O y Br z -based doping strategies generally involve non-metallic elements (e.g., B, C, N, etc.) and metal (usually alkaline earth and transition metal) ion doping [86]. For example, boric acid as a boron source has been used to synthesize B-doped BiOBr (B-BiOBr) nanosheets by hydrothermal method [87]. Due to the electron-deficient nature of boron, it is easy for boron to accept additional electrons from the VB of B-BiOBr. For instance, compared to BiOBr, the band gap decreases, and the maximum valence band (VBM) increases for the B-BiOBr sample. These features result in the improved mobility of photoexcited holes and enhanced oxidation capacity of B-BiOBr. In another case, Geng et al. used an ionic liquid-assisted hydrothermal method to synthesize pristine BiOBr and barium-doped BiOBr (BBA-X, X = 1, 2, 3, 4) with abundant OVs [88]. The successful doping of barium ions in BBA is illustrated by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). Meanwhile, EPR results show that the concentration of OVs in barium-doped BiOBr is much higher than that in pristine BiOBr, and the concentration of OVs in the catalyst increases with the increase of Ba doping amount (Fig. 5 a). This is mainly attributed to the structural distortion caused by the atomic size difference between Ba and Bi, and more OVs may be formed after crystal relaxation. Due to the doping of Ba ions and the existence of OVs, the band gap of BBA is decreased, the edges of VB and CB are also shifted down, and the absorption ability of visible light is enhanced (Fig. 5b). Furthermore, the recombination of carriers is inhibited and the electron mobility is improved, which results in the depression of PL spectra (Fig. 5c). Although metal or non-metal ion doping in BiOBr is a very simple and effective modification method, there are still some unclear issues induced by heteroatom doping at present. For example, the reaction kinetics, and in particular the functional mechanisms of co-doping are less exploited. 3.3 Surface modification The atoms on the catalyst surface can primarily affect the surface energy band structure of materials, and provide reaction sites for photocatalytic reactions [89]. Thanks to the layered structure of Bi x O y Br z with high surface area and open transition crystal structure, surface modification is one of the most effective engineering methods. Especially, the Br− layers in the crystalline structure of Bi x O y Br z can be radially replaced by other functional groups during the bulk/surface engineering processes. As a typical example, Su’s group reported that Bi24O31Br10(OH) δ containing basic sites on the surface could be obtained by a simple microwave-assisted method in a strongly alkaline solution [90]. It is evident from the XPS spectrum (Fig. 5d) that the O 1s spectrum of Bi24O31Br10(OH)δ consists of three peaks of lattice oxygen (OL, 529.8 eV), hydroxyl (531.2 eV) and adsorbed water (532.8 eV). In a strong alkaline environment, the Br− on the catalyst surface was partially replaced by OH−, and active lattice oxygen (OL) was introduced, so that the interplanar spacing of Bi24O31Br10(OH)δ increased compared with ordinary BiOBr. Due to the change of lattice structure, the prepared Bi24O31Br10(OH)δ presents a porous flower-like grid nanostructure, and three different types of OL sites on the catalyst surface of the optimized Bi24O31Br10(OH)δ show low energy similar to the formation of OVs (Fig. 5e). This leads to the generation of more active sites on the catalyst surface, and the loose porous structure allows a large amount of alcohol to diffuse easily into the abundant active surface sites. Meanwhile, the basic sites on the surface of Bi24O31Br10(OH)δ can be used for simultaneous alkaline catalysis during photocatalysis to improve the reactivity of the catalysts, resulting in better selectivity and reaction efficiency. Wang et al. used meso-erythritol (ME) containing many hydroxyl groups to modulate the surface of BiOBr nanosheets to prepare a catalyst containing surface hydroxyl imprinted sites (BiOBr-ME) [91]. As shown in Fig. 5(f and g), compared with pristine BiOBr-W (without special treatment), the average size of BiOBr-ME nanosheets is about 17 nm, which is smaller than that of BiOBr-W (42 nm). In addition, the specific surface area of BiOBr-ME nanosheets (28.57 m2 g−1) is 4 times that of BiOBr-W (6.87 m2 g−1), which indicates that the introduction of ME molecules imparts a vital role in increasing the surface area. Due to the increased specific surface area, there are more active sites on BiOBr-ME, which facilitates the adsorption and degradation of pollutants. Besides, the elevated VBM in BiOBr-ME resulting from the surface modification of hydroxyl groups endows BiOBr-ME with better photooxidative ability compared with BiOBr-W. FT-IR spectra also showed that due to the existence of a large number of hydroxyl imprinted sites on the surface of BiOBr, photogenerated holes were easily captured during the reaction process, thereby generating a large number of hydroxyl radicals for the oxidation reaction (Fig. 5h). It can be concluded that surface modification can modulate the energy band structure of catalysts and provide additional active sites, and sometimes the grafted surface groups can even participate in the reaction as reaction intermediates to boost catalytic efficiency. However, the modification strategies may not be a general engineering strategy as compared to other strategies because it depends on the specific interaction among the modifiers, catalysts, and reactants. 3.4 Bismuth (Bi)-rich engineering Similar to cation vacancy, the Bi-rich strategy is also a very common engineering method based on regulating Bi atoms in bismuth oxyhalide. Compared with pristine BiOBr material, the band structure of Bi-rich Bi x O y Br z is easier to tune because of the difference in elemental composition [92]. In general, tuning Bi x O y Br z with a Bi-rich strategy reduces its bandgap, and an increase in the amount of negative CB minimum and VB maximum edges will result from a higher Bi content [93]. Besides, Bi-rich Bi x O y Br z has more abundant surface atomic configurations, which can meet the requirements of numerous applications by effectively tuning the surface atomic configuration of Bi x O y Brz. For example, Di et al. prepared a Bi-rich Bi4O5Br2 ultrathin nanosheets assisted by ionic liquids [94]. They showed that the band gap of Bi4O5Br2 is narrowed compared to pristine BiOBr (Fig. 6 a). This is mainly because that the increase of Bi content in Bi4O5Br2 changes the strength of Bi 6p orbit, and thus results in Bi4O5Br2 with a more negative CB and a wider VB (Fig. 6b). The change of the energy band structure can promote the generation of more active species (O2 •−), and contribute to enhanced photocatalytic ability. In another work, Zheng et al. prepared a Bi4O5Br2 catalyst with excellent photocatalytic oxidation ability [95]. The results show that the catalyst features a high specific surface area and positively charged surface, which greatly enhances the adsorption and activation ability for reactants. Moreover, the suitable VB potential resulted from the Bi-rich strategy improved the activity for benzyl alcohol oxidation. Similarly, Wang and colleagues prepared a Bi5O7Br nanotube with OVs [96]. Due to the high ratio of Bi to Br enabled by the Bi-rich strategy, Bi5O7Br has higher photostability and stronger visible light response compared to BiOBr. Meanwhile, due to the high concentration of oxygen atoms in Bi5O7Br, its surface is more prone to produce photoinduced OVs, which can further enhance the photocatalytic performance. Specifically, during the water-assisted photochemical reaction, the visible light irradiation can activate the pristine inert surface to generate sufficient surface OVs, which act as surface active sites to participate in the reaction. At the end of the reaction, the catalyst surface is repopulated with surface photoinduced OVs by capturing O atoms from H2O or O2 to re-form a stable structural morphology. Under the synergistic effect of Bi-rich strategy and OVs, Bi5O7Br nanotubes exhibit excellent separation and transfer ability of photogenerated charge carriers along with abundant surface active sites, thus resulting in efficient, stable and sustainable performance in catalytic N2 fixation. This work is an important manifestation of the synergistic effect between different Bi x O y Br z bulk/surface engineering strategies, which improves the stability and photocatalytic activity of the material through a Bi-rich strategy and the selective generation of OVs by lowering the threshold of defect engineering generation. 3.5 Lattice disorder Lattice disorder refers to the intermittent arrangement of atoms in small regions, which results in crystal distortion of a semiconductor. Compared with the widely reported surface modulation methods, there are few reports on lattice disorder as a bulk/surface modulation strategy due to the limitations of various characterization methods. In recent years, lattice disorder has been shown to be effective in modulating the photocatalytic properties of Bi x O y Br z as a new crystal modulation method with the advancement of research [97,98]. For example, Cao et al. successfully fabricated a photochromic BiOBr nanosheet (p-BiOBr-x, x = 1, 2, 3) with lattice strain [99]. The as-prepared p-BiOBr and blank BiOBr were characterized by aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) using high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) images. The results show that the p-BiOBr surface has abundant lattice disorder defects with diameters of 1–5 nm (Fig. 6c), and the region around the lattice disorder defects has more severe lattice distortion (Fig. 6d). Due to the abundant disordered sites on the surface, a large number of coordination unsaturated Bi and O sites are formed (Fig. 6e). These sites have lower adsorption energy of H2O molecules compared with the original BiOBr (Fig. 6f), which favors the generation of a large number of hydroxyl radicals through H2O adsorption and oxidation to promote the subsequent reaction. In addition, the introduction of lattice disorder in BiOBr also significantly inhibits the recombination of photogenerated charge carriers and extends the lifetime of photogenerated charge carriers. Similarly, Feng et al. regulated the photocatalytic performance of BiOBr nanosheets by adjusting the internal strain [100]. The DFT results show that the energy band structure and symmetry of BiOBr can be altered by tuning the internal strain. Note that the introduction of lattice strain into the material is often accompanied by the formation of surface defects such as OVs due to the instability of the crystal structure. Since both the defect concentration and lattice strain have a great impact on the photocatalytic process, it is important to balance the bilateral effects during the preparation of catalysts to reach a synergistically promotive catalytic effect. In a typical example, He and co-workers prepared a series of BiOBr catalysts with both lattice strain and OVs by changing the annealing temperature to modulate the strength of lattice strain and the concentration of OVs [101]. The presence of OVs extends the visible light absorption and forms a trapping state for excited electrons. The decrease in lattice strain can change the energy band symmetry, promote indirect leaps and facilitate charge carrier separation. Since both OVs and lattice strain affect the separation efficiency of photogenerated charge carriers, a suitable annealing temperature induced an appropriate amount of OVs and relaxed lattice strain could further retard the photogenerated charge carrier recombination. For this reason, the BiOBr sample annealed at 200 °C exhibits the best light response and photoactivity. This is the first work to fully demonstrate that when both bulk and surface engineering are present in Bi x O y Br z , the catalytic effect can be further enhanced by balancing the bilateral effects to create synergy in the photocatalytic reaction. 3.6 Crystal planes engineering For efficient photocatalysis, photoexcited charge carriers need to be separated and transferred timely [102]. Among various methods to promote photogenerated electron/hole separation, crystal planes engineering has been considered as a promising method. Particularly, crystal plane engineering based on Bi x O y Br z has attracted much attention because the internal electrostatic field between [Bi2O2]2+ and Br− layer can promote the separation of photoexcited electrons and holes [103]. For example, Wu et al. synthesized BiOBr catalysts (BiOBr-001 and BiOBr-010) with (001) or (010) exposed crystal planes [104]. As shown in Fig. 6(g and h), it can be clearly seen from the high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM) image that for BiOBr-001, the lattice stripes with a spacing of 2.77 Å stands for the BiOBr (110) atomic plane perpendicular to the (001) plane. The corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern shows clear diffraction spots, indicating that the particles are single crystals and have identified diffraction planes (200) and (110), where the angle between them is about 45°, indicating that BiOBr-001 is surrounded by (001). Similarly, it can be proved that the main crystal plane of BiOBr-010 is (010). To evaluate the charge separation efficiency of the two catalysts, the photocurrent response was tested (Fig. 6i). The results show that the photocurrent density of BiOBr-010 is more than twice that of BiOBr-001. This shows that the separation and transfer efficiency of photogenerated charge carriers, even the light utilization, can be enhanced by exposing more (010) crystal planes of BiOBr. In another example, Zhang et al. prepared a BiOBr nanosheet (BiOBr-102) with the main exposed (102) crystal face [105]. They disclosed that BiOBr-102 has a lower CBM level and a higher VBM level as compared with BiOBr with an exposed (001) crystal plane. These lead to better carrier separation efficiency, higher hole redox potential, and wider light absorption range of BiOBr-102. Similarly, Sun et al. synthesized BiOBr porous nanosheets with a main exposure of (110) facet by solvothermal method [106]. Because the (110) facet is the main exposed crystal surface, the catalyst has a strong IEF, which shows good photocatalytic activity in the degradation of pollutants. From the above discussion, it is evident that the reported active crystal plane of Bi x O y Br z is dependent on the specific reactions. In addition, Bi x O y Br z with different exposed crystal planes also accompanies different geometries and electronic structures, so that the crystal plane effects are difficult to distinguish from the morphological effects. A deeper understanding of these interactions can resort to computational studies. 4 Methods for self-adaptive bulk/surface modulation Since the self-adaptive bulk/surface engineering of Bi x O y Br z has a great impact on its photocatalytic performance, it is essential to summarize various methods for the bulk/surface regulation of Bi x O y Br z , so as to incorporate the favorable factors into Bi x O y Br z more effectively and facilely. At present, the methods for self-adaptive bulk/surface regulation of Bi x O y Br z can be classified into two categories, including in-situ synthesis and post-processing (Fig. 7 ). In-situ synthesis refers to the one-step preparation by direct introduction of the environmental microvariation into the catalyst formation process to drive the self-adaption of the catalyst. The post-processing method is to treat the pre-prepared original BiOBr through different methods in the later stage, so as to alter their physicochemical properties. It is meaningful to comprehend the working mechanism of various methods in regulating Bi x O y Br z semiconductors, which can provide more theoretical basis for exploring the roles of self-adaptive engineering in the catalytic process. 4.1 In-situ synthesis Among the two main methods for bulk/surface regulation of Bi x O y Br z , the in-situ synthesis based on hydrothermal method is favored by scholars because of its simplicity and high efficiency. In general, by changing the reaction environment, such as pH, solvent, surfactant, etc., the growth mode of Bi x O y Br z will be changed accordingly during the formation process to deliver the self-adaptively engineered Bi x O y Br z . For example, a reducing solvent is used in the preparation of Bi x O y Br z , which can reduce some atoms in Bi x O y Br z due to the strong reduction power of reducing reagent, so as to synthesize Bi x O y Br z with surface atomic defects in one step. However, the in-situ synthesis method also has some limitations. Because of its relatively mild reaction environment, it can only introduce some defects with low formation energy, such as OVs, or bring about crystal plane regulation. 4.1.1 pH regulation As for the in-situ synthesis of bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z , adjusting the pH of the precursor solution of the reactant has always been considered as an effective modification method. Extensive works have proved that pH value has a greater impact on bismuth oxyhalide materials [31,32,107]. By adjusting the pH value of the reaction solution, the Bi atom content in the Bi x O y Br z can be increased to form a new Bi-rich material, which is conducive to improving visible light absorption and promoting the separation of charge carriers [108]. For example, Su et al. successfully prepared a BiOBr/Bi4O5Br2 material by controlling the alkalinity of the solution in the hydrothermal process [107]. They found that during the preparation process, catalysts with different compositions can be obtained by changing the pH value of the sample solution. When the pH value is 8, pure Bi4O5Br2 is obtained; when the pH value is controlled to 4–7, the BiOBr/Bi4O5Br2 composite with heterojunction can be obtained. Among them, BiOBr/Bi4O5Br2 has good light absorption ability and photogenerated charge carrier separation ability due to its heterostructure, thus showing good photocatalytic performance. In addition, Bi x O y Br z can be controlled to expose specific crystal planes by changing the pH value of the preparation solution. Wu and co-workers prepared a series of BiOBr with mainly exposed (001) or (010) crystal planes by adjusting the pH value [31]. XRD and XPS characterization results show that BiOBr mainly exposes (001) crystal face when the pH value is low and (010) crystal face when the pH value is high. The BiOBr with (010) exposed crystal face shows better photogenerated charge carrier separation efficiency and better light absorption capacity. 4.1.2 Solvent exchange During the synthetic process, the physical and chemical properties of the catalyst can be greatly altered by changing the reaction solvent, and defect sites can be introduced into the catalyst simultaneously to modulate the photocatalytic performance of the catalyst. For example, Kong and co-workers used EG as an auxiliary solvent in the preparation of Bi x O y Br z , and directly obtained BiOBr rich in OVs after hydrothermal treatment [28]. In addition, by changing the solvent ratio, the surface morphology of BiOBr can be effectively adjusted while introducing OVs [29]. The introduction of OVs is beneficial to photocatalytic activity improvement, while the morphology change can increase the specific surface area of the catalyst and deliver more active sites. In another example, Liao et al. successfully prepared BiOBr catalysts with different surface OV concentrations by adjusting the ratio of EG to H2O in the reaction solvent [30]. Among them, the sample with the highest OVs concentration has the best NO removal efficiency (38.7%), which is much higher than that of the catalyst without OVs (3.8%). This is mainly because with increasing the volume of EG in the solvent, the samples gradually assembled into microspheres, and the size and thickness of the nanoplates decreased, which offers a larger specific surface area for the adsorption and oxidation of NO. 4.1.3 Surfactant addition For 2D layered materials, it is a common and efficient approach to employ surfactants to regulate the catalyst [109]. In general, surfactants can affect the shape, size, and exposed crystal surface of catalysts, and also can be used as stabilizers due to their spatial effects [110,111]. Specifically, Zhang et al. prepared a BiOBr-PVP composite directly by precipitation method with PVP as the surfactant [27]. The BiOBr-PVP shows similar morphologies to BiOBr, but is thinner and smaller in size, which indicates more active sites and a larger specific surface area. Moreover, the addition of PVP increased the exposure of active (001) crystal surface. In terms of light utilization, the presence of appropriate PVP slightly reduced the band gap and increased the light absorption capacity. Therefore, BiOBr-PVP shows extremely excellent photocatalytic performance of pollutants degradation. In another report, Bárdos et al. prepared a series of Bi x O y Br z samples by adding different surfactants (CTAB, PVP, SDS-sodium dodecyl sulfate, U-urea, and TU-thiourea) [25]. They found that when PVP or TU was added to the synthesis process, the ratio of (110) to (102) crystal planes increased. In addition, compared with original BiOBr, the size of the prepared catalyst decreased. Among them, the addition of TU and PVP leads to the smallest average diameter of the smallest fractional crystal size, which is advantageous to the photocatalytic reactions. More importantly, they found that the surface tension of the synthetic solution can be changed by adding surfactants, and appropriate surface tension can introduce high concentrations of Bi4+ and Bi5+ into the BiOBr sample, thus enhancing the photocatalytic performance. 4.2 Post-treatment method Compared with the in-situ synthesis method, the post-processing method is more complex but more controllable. Generally, the post-processing method is used to introduce defects into Bi x O y Br z . By controlling the processing conditions, the density of defects generated on Bi x O y Br z can be generated in a more accurately controlled meaner. In addition, the post-treatment method can also achieve the regeneration of defects under certain conditions. At present, the post-processing methods for modification of Bi x O y Br z mainly include heat treatment, chemical reduction, and ultraviolet (UV) excitation. 4.2.1 Heat treatment In general, the thermal treatment of semiconductor materials can accelerate the escape of atoms on the surface of the material, thereby introducing defects [112]. For example, heating pristine BiOBr nanoplates under a vacuum can introduce OVs into the material [72]. This is mainly because O atoms can easily escape from the lattice under the heating and isolation of air conditions. Theoretically, annealing the BiOBr precursor at different temperatures can tune the concentration of OVs in BiOBr. Cui et al. control the OV concentration in BiOBr by annealing the as-prepared BiOBr nanoplates at different temperatures (200, 300, and 400 °C) [101]. After annealing the pristine BiOBr, the light absorption range was expanded. In addition to introducing surface defects, heat treatment under specific conditions can also remove halogen atoms and change the molar ratio of O/Bi, thus forming a heterojunction structure. Xu et al. successfully synthesized one-dimensional BiOBr-Bi4O5Br2 heterostructures by calcining BiOBr precursors in the air at 450 °C [113]. Due to the formation of the heterostructure, the separation efficiency of photogenerated charge carriers is effectively promoted. In parallel, because of the high interface quality, the resistance of photogenerated charge carriers to pass through the BiOBr-Bi4O5Br2 heterostructure is greatly reduced. Lu et al. reported the iron sites anchored defective BiOBr nanosheets (BiOBrov-Fe) that were prepared by heat treating the original BiOBr in a reducing atmosphere (5 vol.% H2 and 95 vol.% Ar) at a heating rate of 5 K min−1 at 623 K, and then anchoring the iron site on the BiOBrov material (Fig. 8 a) [114]. Under light excitation, the prepared catalysts showed excellent conversion and selectivity in the aerobic oxidative coupling of amines and the selective oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides. The syngenetic introduction of OVs and Fe3+ species on the surface of BiOBr nanosheet not only promote the separation and transfer of photogenerated charge carriers, but also enhance the ability to adsorb and activate O2 molecules into singlet oxygen (1O2). 4.2.2 Chemical reduction Chemical reduction offers a facile route to engineer the bulk/surface properties of Bi x O y Br z . In general, reducing agents (such as NaBH4, KBH4, CaH2, N2H4, NaH, etc.) or reducing solvents (such as ethanol, methanol, EG, etc.) can be used to treat BiOBr to cause bulk/surface re-organization. Iama et al. prepared Bi/BiOBr composites by treating pristine BiOBr with NaBH4 as a reducing agent [115]. During the preparation process, due to the strong reducibility of NaBH4, the Bi element in BiOBr was reduced and deposited on the surface of BiOBr to form a Bi/BiOBr composite. Because of the presence of surface metal Bi, the band gap of the composite material was decreased, so the light absorption ability was improved. Meanwhile, the use of NaBH4 greatly changes the morphology of the catalyst and affords more active sites for catalytic reactions. Chen and co-workers first synthesized transition metal doped BiOBr nanosheets (named BiOBr-M−x, where M signifies Fe, Mo, and Ni, the x represents the molar ratio of M) by a mild hydrothermal process, and then introduced OVs into the prepared BiOBr-M−x sample with EG solution as the reducing solvent to obtain the BiOBr-M−S−x catalyst (Fig. 8b) [116]. EPR spectrum shows that after the second-step solvothermal treatment, the sample exhibits a strong OVs signal at g = 2.003, while no obvious signal is observed in the original BiOBr. A large number of OVs are introduced since the EG can react and associate with the lattice oxygen on the surface of BiOBr, which is then selectively removed under the reducing atmosphere. 4.2.3 UV excitation Irradiating semiconductor materials by UV light is a feasible approach to introduce structural defects [117]. When irradiated by high-power UV light, the Bi–O bond is easily broken because of its low bond energy to introduce OVs on the surface of the material. As shown in Fig. 8(c), the original BiOBr is firstly ultrasonically dispersed to form a BiOBr atomic layer; a large number of OVs can be introduced when the BiOBr atomic layer is irradiated with UV light since the exposed (001) surface of BiOBr atomic layer has a high oxygen atom density. In addition, UV excitation can also reduce Bi ions in BiOBr to metallic Bi to form Bi/BiOBr heterojunction [118]. For example, Jia et al. introduced both OVs and elemental Bi on the surface of BiOBr/RGO composites by UV excitation [119]. The as-formed metallic Bi can enhance the light absorption ability of the material through surface plasmon resonance (SPR) effect. In addition, by controlling the irradiation time of UV light, the amount of deposited Bi and the concentration of OVs can be precisely controlled. Note that since the UV light can destroy the surface atomic organization of BiOBr, the possible photocorrosion phenomenon of the catalyst should also be noticed during the modification or application processes under the UV light irradiation. Although both in-situ synthesis and post-treatment methods enable successful bulk/surface modulation of Bi x O y Br z , some issues brought by the above approaches should be noted. For example, small distinctions in reaction conditions could result in dramatic differences in the as-prepared materials by the in-situ synthesis method, so it is hard to precisely control. The post-treatment method can effectively modulate the density or location of the introduced bulk/surface difference by changing the treating time and conditions, but it needs higher energy consumption. Therefore, developing more efficient and controllable self-adaptive bulk/surface tuning methods becomes a relentless goal of scholars. Recently, novel methods such as plasma etching [120] and ball milling method [121] have been discovered in other semiconductor materials, which certainly provides new inspirations for the bulk/surface engineering of Bi x O y Br z . 5 Photocatalytic applications Bi x O y Br z is generally employed in photocatalytic oxidation reactions due to the suitable energy band structure. In terms of reduction reactions, the pristine BiOBr works unsatisfactorily due to the limitation of the CB location. However, benefiting from diverse bulk/surface engineering strategies, which can alter the energy band structure, carrier concentration, and interfacial catalytic ability of the semiconductors, engineered Bi x O y Br z shows great application potential in both photoreduction and photooxidation reactions. Nowadays, more and more scholars have begun to participate in the fields of photocatalytic CO2 reduction, H2O splitting and N2 fixation with engineered Bi x O y Br z as the catalyst and have achieved encouraging results. 5.1 Photocatalytic environmental remediation Semiconductor-based photocatalysis is a very promising channel for the degradation of pollutants and has shown great potential in environmental remediation [122,123]. Bi x O y Br z has a positive VB potential, which can provide enough thermodynamic energy for photogenerated holes to directly oxidize organic pollutants [124]. In addition, when Bi x O y Br z degrades pollutants in the presence of, photogenerated electrons in CB can react with oxygen adsorbed on the catalyst surface, to deliver superoxide radicals (•O2 −), and photogenerated holes in VB can oxidize H2O molecules to hydroxyl radicals (•OH). The above reaction paths are based on charge carrier transfer processes. In some cases, the absorbed energy by Bi x O y Br z can be accepted by O2 to give the singlet oxygen (1O2) through the energy transfer path. These produced ROSs and holes are the main reactive species that responded to environmental remediation [125]. In the following part, we will discuss the typical examples of bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z for various environmental remediation applications, including dye degradation, medicinal molecules degradation and bacterial inactivation, and all the studies are summarized in Table 1 for clear comparison. 5.1.1 Dye degradation With the continuous progress of modern industry, a large number of dyes are discharged into the environment every year. The discharge of dye pollutants into water will aggravate the consumption of oxygen and limit the propagation of light in water, thus seriously affecting its ecological environment. Therefore, how to control and deal with the environmental pollution caused by dyeing wastewater discharge has always been one of the core concerns for worldwide scientists. In the past decade, the use of photocatalytic technology to degrade dyes in water has become a research hotspot. The design of photocatalysts with high catalytic activity, and good stability under visible light irradiation is the key to constructing high-efficiency photocatalytic systems for practical applications. Due to its green, economic, strong oxidation capacity, and other advantages, Bi x O y Br z -based photocatalysts have been widely exploited [126]. For example, Geng et al. synthesized Bi/BiOBr composites containing OVs by combustion method and prepared Bi/BiOBr-X (X = 2–4, X is the molar ratio of reducing Br source to Bi source in the preparation process) with different metal Bi content by changing the molar ratio of reductant to Bi source [127]. Compared with pure BiOBr, the as-prepared Bi/BiOBr-x material greatly enhances the light absorption capacity and has a larger specific surface area, which is beneficial to the adsorption of Rhodamine B (RhB). The obtained Bi/BiOBr-3 has the lowest electron-hole recombination rate and the best degradation effect for RhB. As shown in Fig. 9 (a), the photocatalytic performance of the prepared Bi/BiOBr-X catalyst was much superior to that of pure BiOBr (BOB-NS) and TiO2 (P25). After 30 min of irradiation, the degradation rate of RhB by Bi/BiOBr-3 was 95.2%, much higher than 23.9% of pure BiOBr. This is mainly because the OVs in the catalyst form impurity energy levels between the VB and the CB, which reduces the band gap of BiOBr (Fig. 9b). In addition, the metal Bi on the surface of Bi/BiOBr generates a large number of hot electrons injected into the CB of BiOBr through the SPR effect, which greatly improves the utilization of photons by the catalyst. Then, the active species that play a key role in the reaction were explored by adding various active species quenchers to the reaction system. The results showed that •O2 − and holes greatly contributed to the photocatalytic degradation, while •OH did not contribute to the reaction. In another work, Qiao et al. fabricated BiOBr/Bi24O31Br10 heterojunctions with surface OVs [128]. Under pH-neutral conditions, due to the existence of surface OVs, the sample surface is positively charged, which has a strong adsorption effect on anionic methyl orange (MO). In addition, because of the electrostatic interaction between the OV and the hydroxyl ionized in water, the H atom on the hydroxyl forms a hydrogen bond with the N atom on RhB, thereby enhancing the adsorption of the cation RhB. Finally, the samples containing 75.2% BiOBr and 24.8% Bi24O31Br10 exhibited the best photocatalytic degradation activity under the synergistic effect of OVs and heterojunction structures. The reaction rate constants of the catalyst for the degradation of 50 mg/L RhB and 30 mg/L MO were 4.0 and 9.0 times higher than those of pure BiOBr, respectively under visible light irradiation. This work provides a facile one-step combustion method to synthesize BiOBr based heterostructures with surface defects towards enhanced photocatalytic activities. Zou and co-workers synthesized a series of BiOBr layered photocatalysts (BiOBr-x, x = 0, 2.5, 6, 10) with tunable IEF and surface OVs [129]. As shown in Fig. 9(c), the difference in sheet thickness leads to different IEF strengths in the whole layered structure of the catalyst. As the thickness of the BiOBr layer decreases, the intensity of the IEF in the catalyst increases, thereby suppressing the recombination of the photogenerated support and significantly improving the light-harvesting efficiency. Due to the synergistic effect of IEF and OVs, the as-prepared BiOBr-2.5 catalyst exhibits an excellent degradation rate for RhB solution (50 mL 20 mg L−1), i.e., 99.8% in the reaction time of 180 min, which was much higher than 52.9% of the original BiOBr (BiOBr-0). Hou et al. synthesized a series of BiOBr nanosheets with adjustable exposure surfaces and microcrystalline size [130]. They demonstrated that the thinner thickness of nanosheets was conducive to the transfer and separation of photogenerated charge carriers. Furthermore, the samples with (001) crystal plane as the main exposed crystal plane have higher IEF, which also leads to the improvement of photocatalytic performance towards the degradation of RhB. 5.1.2 Medicinal molecules degradation In recent years, with the continuous progress of medical technology, the concentration of some common drugs such as antibiotics in wastewater has increased year by year. To reduce the toxicity of drug pollutants in water to organisms and the environment, photocatalytic degradation of drug molecules in water has been extensively researched [131,132]. Sun et al. modified the surface of BiOBr with glucose to prepare the BiOBr-X material (X = 3, 5, 7, 10) with a large number of hydroxyl groups on the surface [133]. The as-designed catalyst was applied to the degradation of levofloxacin hydrochloride (LVF), which is a commonly used antibiotic (Fig. 9d). The presence of surface hydroxyl groups provides a large number of active sites for photocatalytic degradation and accelerates the transfer of photogenerated charge carriers. Moreover, free radical scavenging experiments show that •OH plays the most imperative role in the reaction system of degrading LVF. The hydroxyl group on the surface of BiOBr-X can react with adsorbed water to form more •OH, thereby enhancing the degradation efficiency of LVF (Fig. 9e). The degradation rate of BiOBr-5 composite to LVF can reach 91.67% in 20 min, while the degradation rate of original BiOBr to LVF can only reach 59.26% within the same time. Yu et al. reported an S-doped BiOBr (S-BiOBr) via a solvothermal process with thioureas as the dopant and applied it to the degradation of ibuprofen (IBF), a widely used analgesic [134]. The doping of S element can substitute O in the lattice, thus forming OVs in the BiOBr, which further tunes the energy band structure of BiOBr, and greatly enhance the utilization efficiency for visible light. Finally, the photocatalytic test shows that the degradation ability of S-BiOBr to IBF is much higher than that of pristine BiOBr, and the degradation kinetic constant of S-BiOBr (2.48 × 10−2 min−1) is about 3 times that of the original BiOBr (0.83 × 10−2 min−1). Dong et al. modified BiOBr with carbon quantum dots (CQDs) by a two-step hydrothermal method and prepared OVs rich composites (CQDs/BiOBr) with (001) plane as the main exposed surface [135]. Under visible light irradiation, the obtained composite can simultaneously remove tetracycline hydrochloride (TCH) and Cr (VI) and shows a very excellent degradation under the condition of pH = 3. It is interesting to note that the photocatalytic reaction rate constant in the coexisting of pollutant system is 3.71 times (TCH) and 13.6 times (Cr (VI)) higher than that in the single pollutant system. This work provides a promising method to design dual-function BiOBr-based photocatalysts with synchronously formed OVs and dominant crystal facet for the simultaneous removal of coexisting pollutants in wastewater. Inspired by these results, more attention could be devoted to developing highly efficient catalysts for the treatment of wastewater with multiple pollutants to realize the practical environmental remediation in the near future. 5.1.3 Bacterial inactivation Due to the increasing environmental pollution, the ubiquitous harmful bacteria in the living environment have caused a serious impact on human production and life. These impacts get stronger during the current pandemic. As a relatively green and stable photocatalyst, it is anticipated that the engineered Bi x O y Br z -based photocatalysts could have broad applications in antibacterial [136]. Wong et al. prepared BiOBr nanosheets (B001 and B010) with OVs and exposed crystal planes of (001) or (010) [31]. These catalysts were applied to the photocatalytic inactivation of Escherichia coli K-12 (E. coli K-12). They found that the B001 nanosheet with more exposed active (001) crystal facet possesses more OVs than the B010 nanosheet. This endows B001 with faster photogenerated charge carrier separation and transfer efficiency in the reaction process and produce more •O2 −. Studies on the inactivation mechanism of E. coli K-12 showed that h+ and •O2 − were considered to be the main active substances for bacterial inactivation in both B001 and B010 photocatalysts (Fig. 9f). Under visible light irradiation, the optimized catalyst B001 showed excellent sterilization performance, which can fully inactivate 7-log bacterial cells within 2 h. Li et al. fabricated a BiO2- x /BiOBr Z-type heterojunction by in-situ surface re-organization [137]. The synergistic effect between OVs and Z-type heterojunction structure results in an extremely wide range of applications and excellent photocatalytic performance. The optimal BiO2- x /BiOBr heterojunction could degrade 99.8% RhB in 60 min and 79% TC in 90 min, and could completely inactivate E. coli and staphylococcus aureus in 20 min. This study presents a new surface/interface re-organization method for constructing BiOBr based heterostructure materials with high redox capacity and enriches their application in environmental purification. However, the effect of inorganic ions, pH value, and water matrix on the practical application of the materials are still not very clear, and further studies are needed to resolve the restrictions from these aspects and facilitate the applications in real wastewater systems. 5.2 Photocatalytic solar fuel production Photocatalytic solar fuel production has become vitally important as it is the most promising strategy to replace fossil fuels with renewable energy sources [148]. Past decades have witnessed prosperous research on various solar fuel production, such as H2 production from H2O splitting, the transformation of CO2 to carbon fuels, and ammonia production by N2 fixation [149–151]. In general, pristine BiOBr is not commonly used for these photocatalytic reduction reactions due to the limited activity determined by the low CB position. However, recent extensive research input to the field of bulk/surface engineering of Bi x O y Br z spotlighted the great potential and possibility to promote the CB position of BiOBr to achieving the energetically uphill solar energy conversion reactions. In the following part, we will discuss the typical examples of bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z applied in the area of solar fuel production, such as H2O reduction, CO2 reduction, and N2 fixation, and all the studies are summarized in Table 2 for clear comparison. 5.2.1 H2O reduction Due to the current shortage of energy sources in the world, it is urgent to find a sustainable way to use renewable energy. H2 as a green fuel has engrossed the attention of researchers from every country. Although there has been a great breakthrough in the decomposition of H2O to H2 by photocatalysis [152–154], the development of this field is still limited due to the low energy conversion efficiency. For pristine BiOBr, due to its special energy band structure, its photocatalytic H2 evolution performance is very poor. The bulk/surface engineering can tune the electronic structure of Bi x O y Br z , thereby enhancing its photocatalytic H2 evolution capability [155]. For example, He et al. prepared BiOBr nanosheets on the surface of carbon fibers (CFS) and found that when the contact mode between BiOBr and CFS is different, the H2 evolution effect is also different [156]. When BiOBr and CFS are combined, two kinds of Schottky heterojunction structures, parallel BiOBr/C junctions, and vertical BiOBr/C junctions will be formed, and OVs will be introduced into the contact surface. Among them, the OVs concentration on the contact surface of parallel BiOBr/C junctions is much higher than that on the contact surface of vertical BiOBr/C junctions. Compared with pristine BiOBr and CFS, the catalysts with heterojunctions have stronger light absorption capacity and narrower band gaps (Fig. 10 a and b). Additionally, due to the short electron transmission path of parallel connection, BiOBr/C junctions show excellent charge carrier transfer and finally a significant photocatalytic H2 evolution performance of 2850 μmol g−1h −1 (Fig. 10c). Ye et al. prepared Bi-rich Bi4O5Br2 and Bi4O5I2 and compared their photocatalytic H2 evolution performance [157]. The results show that Bi4O5Br2 can provide a H2 production rate of 170.25 μmol g−1h −1, which is ∼1.65 times as Bi4O5I2. This is because that the thinner thickness of Bi4O5Br2 generates a strong IEF on its surface, which promotes the separation efficiency of photogenerated charge carriers and thus promotes photocatalytic H2 evolution. A similar example is that OV-BiOBr/Cu2- x S-X (X is the molar ratio of Cu2- x S to OV-BiOBr, X = 0.1, 0.2, 0.3) with double defects (oxygen defect and copper defect) was used as the catalyst for H2 evolution [158]. As shown in Fig. 10(d), the interfacial polarization of the catalyst is enhanced under the synergistic effect of the double defects, and a polarized electric field (PEF) is formed between the two materials during the photocatalytic reaction. Meanwhile, an IEF is formed due to the different Fermi levels of the two materials. After illumination, because of the synergistic effect of PEF and IEF, the photogenerated electrons migrate to the OV-BiOBr side, and the photogenerated holes transfer to the CuS side, thus realizing the effective spatial separation and transfer of charge carriers. Because of this unique synergistic effect, the catalyst showed good stability and excellent activity (Fig. 10e). OV-BiOBr/Cu2- x S-0.2 still shows high H2 generation activity after four cycles (10 h light irradiation) and maintains high stability. In addition, the H2 evolution rate of OV-BiOBr/Cu2- x S-0.2 under visible light irradiation and external electric field was 509.37 μmol cm−2h−1, which was 12.45, 6.94 and 3.44 times that of BiOBr, OV-BiOBr, and BiOBr/Cu2- x S, respectively (Fig. 10f). These works lay a scientific and experimental foundation for the preparation of bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z materials with high performance for the H2 generation, which provides an avenue toward constructing reasonable Bi x O y Br z -based heterostructures for boosted H2 evolution. 5.2.2 CO2 reduction In recent decades, the exhaustive exploitation of fossil fuels has not only brought increasing energy problems but also increased the emission of CO2 into the atmosphere, and the latter has been regarded as the main reason for global warming [159]. Using photocatalytic technology to reduce CO2 to produce fuels and chemicals such as CO, CH4, HCHO, CH3OH or HCOOH can alleviate the current energy crisis while reducing the greenhouse effect [160,161]. Recent researches show that Bi x O y Br z has great potential in CO2 reduction due to its special physical and electronic structure [78]. The bulk/surface engineering of Bi x O y Br z can further improve the photocatalytic CO2 reduction performance. For example, a series of layered hollow BiOBr microspheres with rich OVs were prepared by just tuning the reaction temperature during the preparation process [162]. As shown in Fig. 11 (a), the hollow microsphere like BiOBr prepared at 120 °C has a larger specific surface area and provides more active sites. At the same time, multiple light reflections are generated in the cavity during illumination, which greatly improves the utilization efficiency of light. In addition, the existence of OVs induces the enrichment of the charge density of BiOBr, which greatly enhances the adsorption capacity of BiOBr for CO2 with Lewis acid characteristics, enhances the stability of CO2 reduction intermediates, and significantly reduces the activation barrier of CO2. Therefore, under the synergistic effect of the morphology of layered hollow microspheres and OVs, the catalyst prepared at 120 °C showed excellent CO2 reduction performance, and the release rates of CO and CH4 on the catalyst were 88.1 and 5.8 mmol g−1h −1, respectively, which were 8.8 times and 5.8 times higher than the plate-like BiOBr prepared at 100 °C (Fig. 11b). This work demonstrates the possibility of utilizing Bi x O y Br z materials for noble-metal-free reduction of CO2 into energy fuels via the vacancy engineering strategy. The bulk/surface engineering of Bi x O y Br z can not only improve the activity of CO2 reduction, but also regulate the selectivity of reduction products. Wu et al. prepared BiOBr nanosheets mainly with (001) exposed surface by adjusting the pH of the reaction solution during catalyst preparation [32]. The catalyst showed high selectivity for photocatalytic conversion of CO2 to CO, and no CH4 could be detected in the product. Compared with original BiOBr, which only produces negligible CO and CH4 gas, the modified BiOBr has an enhanced CO yield of 4.45 µmol g−1h −1. Hou et al. prepared a series of La-doped flower-like BiOBr catalysts (BiOBr/La) [163]. Among them, the prepared BiOBr/La-4.9% exhibited a good photocatalytic CO2 conversion rate (22.77 μmol g−1h −1), and the selectivity to CH3OH in the reduction product reached 92.41% (Fig. 11c). This is mainly because as compared to pure BiOBr, BiOBr/La has greater lattice expansion and more OVs due to La doping. In addition, as shown in Fig. 11(d), La doping makes the conduction potential of the catalyst more negative than the redox potential of E0 (CO2/CH3OH), so that the photogenerated e− in the CB of the catalyst can reduce CO2 to CH3OH more easily and the selectivity towards CH3OH was improved. Based on the Bi-rich strategy, Ye et al. prepared a Bi4O5Br2 microsphere assembled from ultrathin BiOBr nanosheets [164]. The photocatalytic CO2 reduction experiments show that the CO and CH4 produced by Bi4O5Br2 are about 2.73 and 2.04 µmol g−1h −1, which are much higher than that of ultrathin BiOBr (CO:2.67 µmol g−1h −1; CH4:0.16 µmol g−1h −1). More importantly, they found that changing the thickness of the nanosheet and the proportion of Bi in the catalyst will have different effects on the reduction of CO2. Among them, reducing the thickness of nanosheets can increase the generation of CO, while adopting a Bi-rich strategy can increase the production of CH4 in CO2 photoreduction products (Fig. 11e).
