These works manifest that the ultrathin Bi x O y Br z nanosheet exhibits great potential towards CO2 reduction by overcoming the pristine band gap limitations of blank Bi x O y Br z semiconductor, which casts a promising direction for developing ultrathin nanostructure of Bi x O y Br z -based materials towards CO2 reduction. 5.2.3 N2 Fixation Ammonia (NH3) is one of the most widely produced chemicals in the modern chemical industry, and has long been considered a green economy energy source due to its high hydrogen content and high energy density [165]. The Haber-Bosch process is generally used to convert N2 into ammonia in conventional industries. However, this process requires a high temperature of 300–500 °C and high pressure of 15–25 MPa conditions [166]. This leads to the consumption of huge energy, and also the production of a large amount of CO2 during the process of N2 conversion [167,168]. Therefore, to seek a low-carbon and energy-saving way of ammonia synthesis, Bi x O y Br z -based photocatalytic N2 fixation has attracted extensive attention. Compared with Bi x O y Br z -based photocatalytic CO2 reduction, photocatalytic N2 fixation is more challenging [51]. This is mainly due to the higher dissociation energy of N≡N (962 kJ mol−1) and the weaker binding ability of N2 molecules to the catalyst surface [60]. The bulk/surface engineering of Bi x O y Br z has been established to be a successful strategy for the N2 activation and thus favors the subsequent N2 reduction process [169,170]. For example, Jin and co-workers adopted a general hydrothermal method to synthesize BiOBr nanosheets with (001) as the major exposed crystal plane and abundant OVs (VO-BiOBr) [42]. They investigated the photocatalytic N2 fixation activity of VO-BiOBr with distilled water as the reaction solvent and proton source, and the concentration of generated ammonia was measured by Nessler reagent colorimetry. The photocatalytic test displays that the VO-BiOBr nanosheets containing OVs have better photocatalytic N2 fixation activity than the original BiOBr. The average rate of photocatalytic ammonia generation over VO-BiOBr nanosheets is 54.7 µmol g−1h −1, which is much higher than the 5.75 µmol g−1h −1 over the original BiOBr nanosheets (Fig. 12 a). The existence of OVs can effectively capture and activate inert N2 molecules. When N2 is adsorbed on the OVs of the VO-BiOBr (001) facet, it will be activated and the bond length of N≡N increases from 1.11 to 1.24 Å. The adsorbed N2 is subsequently hydrogenated to form an ammonia intermediate, which is finally reduced to an ammonia gas molecule. This work points out that the OV engineering on Bi x O y Br z provides a feasible way to boost the rate of ammonia synthesis under mild conditions. Zhang et al. reported the BiOBr microspheres (Bi@BiOBr) containing both OVs and Bi modifications by a facile one-pot method [171]. As represented in Fig. 12(b), during the reaction process of photocatalytic N2 reduction, OVs act as the adsorption site and activation center of N2, while the Bi metal on the catalyst surface can provide more hot electrons for the catalytic process through the SPR effect. In addition, OVs and elemental Bi also act as electron traps, inhibiting the recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes and finally reducing activated N2 to NH3. Therefore, the introduction of OVs and elemental Bi greatly improved the photocatalytic N2 fixation efficiency of the catalyst, and the reduction rate of the optimal sample is 1350 μmol g −1h −1. To further enhance the photocatalytic N2 fixation performance of engineered Bi x O y Br z , it can be combined with other materials during bulk/surface engineering. Recently, Chen et al. prepared a BiOBr/MXene-Ti3C2 composite catalyst containing both OVs and Ti vacancies [172]. As shown in Fig. 12(c), when MXene-Ti3C2 is combined with BiOBr, MXene shows metal-like properties and produces a built-in electric field at the contact local interface (Schottky junction), which promotes the transfer of local interface charge and the multi-electron reduction of N2. In addition, because of the simultaneous existence of OVs and Ti vacancies, it can induce the deformation structure of the catalyst, thus greatly enhancing the chemical adsorption of N2 molecules. This effectively prolongs the bond length of N≡N (Fig. 12d), making it easier for photogenerated electrons to reduce N2 molecules at the defect location, and ultimately induce the formation of NH3 or NH4 +. Therefore, in comparison to pure BiOBr and Ti3C2, BiOBr/MXene-Ti3C2 composite shows extremely excellent photocatalytic N2 fixation performance, and the ammonia generation rate of 10wt% BiOBr/MXene-Ti3C2 is 234.6 μmol g −1h −1, which is about 48.8 times and 52.4 times higher than pure BiOBr and Ti3C2, respectively (Fig. 12e). In another example, Jin et al. prepared a heterojunction based on n-type Bi2MoO6 nanorods and p-type BiOBr nanosheets rich in OVs (Bi2MoO6/OV-BiOBr) [173]. The catalyst showed excellent photocatalytic N2 fixation performance (90.7 μmol g−1h −1) in absence of any sacrificial agents and noble metal cocatalysts, which is 30 times and 3 times higher than the original Bi2MoO6 nanorods (3.0 μmol g−1h −1) and BiOBr nanosheets (31.2 μmol g−1h −1) respectively. These studies provide new insights into the synergistic effect of heterojunctions and defects construction over Bi x O y Br z for N2 conversion to NH3 without any noble metal co-catalysts and sacrificial reagents under ambient conditions, which inspires the future rational design of catalysts by surface/bulk engineering in the field of catalytic synthesis of NH3. 5.3 Photocatalytic organic synthesis Organic reactions aim to produce industrially important chemicals. For a long time, the synthesis of organic chemicals has been mainly carried out by thermal catalysis, but thermal catalytic activation generally needs to be carried out under high pressure and high-temperature reaction conditions and will produce side reactions, which is not conducive to the isolation [179]. For this reason, photocatalytic organic synthesis is expected to be a new opportunity for organic reactions due to its green and mild reaction conditions. At present, some progress has been made in using semiconductor photocatalysts to oxidize organic molecules (for example, amines, alcohols, and alkanes) with high selectivity [180–184], but the performance of related photocatalysts is far from satisfactory. With the assistance of self-adaptive bulk/surface engineering, Bi x O y Br z is considered as an excellent semiconductor model due to its suitable energy band structure and special layered structure. For example, Li and co-workers prepared an ultrathin BiOBr nanosheet with OVs (BiOBr-XEG, X = 0, 15, 25, 30) and applied it to oxidizing secondary amines [185]. The OVs concentrations are modulated by a facile solvothermal process with water, EG, and PVP as the mixed solvent, and follow the trend of BiOBr-25EG > BiOBr-15EG > BiOBr-0EG > BiOBr-30EG. As shown in Fig. 13 (a), the photoactivity variation is consistent with the trend of OV concentration in the samples, and all samples exhibited extremely high selectivity (>96%). To interpret these results, they conducted an in-depth investigation on both the structural features and reaction mechanism of BiOBr-XEG. The results show that OVs lead to a narrow band gap, which enhances the absorption of visible light. Moreover, the OVs generate a defective energy state below the CB of BiOBr, which promotes the leap and transfer of electrons in the CB to the catalyst surface, thus facilitating the separation of photogenerated charge carriers (Fig. 13b). As a result, the enhanced light absorption as well as the accelerated charge carrier separation collectively boost the photocatalytic oxidation of secondary amines. This work not only provides a facile method to construct OVs with a controllable meaner, but also highlights the competency of surface engineered BiOBr applying in the important area of organic synthesis. Similarly, Li et al. prepared a BiOBr catalyst with both OVs and Pd sites on the surface (Pd/BiOBr) [186]. DFT calculations indicated that the simultaneous introduction of OVs and Pd sites in BiOBr facilitated the adsorption of O2 and toluene. At the same time, the presence of Pd introduces more OVs into BiOBr and forms a Schottky barrier at the interface to suppress the recombination of photogenerated charge carriers. As shown in Fig. 13(c), photogenerated electrons and holes accumulate at different sites during the photocatalytic reaction. The chemisorbed O2 is reduced to reactive oxygen species (•O2 − and 1O2) by electrons, and the C(sp3)–H bond of toluene is oxidized by holes to form benzyl groups. The resulting reactive oxygen species react with the activated benzyl intermediate to finally generate benzaldehyde and H2O. The final experimental results show that Pd/BiOBr exhibits good conversion (320.6–549.5 μmol gcat −1h−1) and exceptional selectivity (>99%) in the photocatalytic oxidation of p-toluene and its derivatives (Fig. 13d). This work pushes a series of the interfacial synergy of metal sites and OV for promoting the photocatalytic performance of Bi x O y Br z for selective oxidation reactions and is expected to guide future structural design and modulation for more wide applications. In another case, Dai et al. prepared a Bi24O31Br10(OH)δ catalyst by modifying the pristine BiOBr surface and anchoring base sites [187]. The basic sites on the surface of the catalyst can optimize the hydrogen transfer process during organic synthesis reactions, thereby improving the reaction performance. As shown in Fig. 13(e), the basic sites (surface hydroxyl and O atoms with low coordination numbers) on the catalyst surface can form metastable surfaces to adsorb H (Hads) and under light irradiation promotes the oxidation of alcohols. After the irradiation, they bind to the hydrogen acceptor (A) to complete the reaction, instead of generating H2 gas. Based on this catalytic recycle, the optimization of the hydrogen transfer path greatly improves the quantum efficiency of Bi24O31Br10(OH)δ in organic synthesis reactions, in which the quantum efficiency of nitrobenzene reduction reaches 42% and 32% under 410 nm and 450 nm radiation, respectively. The work demonstrates the synergy between bulk/surface engineering and photocatalysis, which carries in an unprecedented platform for organics oxidation synthesis. For a clear comparison, the above applications of various self-adaptive bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z for organic synthesis are summarized in Table 3 . 6 Summary and outlook In this review, we endeavored to clarify the structural features of bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z materials in terms of morphology, surface state, crystalline, and electronic structure. The controllable modulation strategies, working mechanisms, and photocatalytic applications of engineered Bi x O y Br z materials were comprehensively reviewed and discussed, aiming to deliver a better understanding and good guidance for future studies. It can be concluded that Bi x O y Br z -based semiconductors exhibit remarkable prospects in the areas of catalytic energy conversion and environmental remediation. Although noteworthy progress has been accomplished, ongoing efforts are still demanded to promote further fundamental research on self-adaptive bulk/surface modulated Bi x O y Br z as well as their realistic applications. Overall, the following aspects deserve urgent attention in future studies for the early realization of their practical values as expected. (I) Charge separation still remains challenging in obtaining high photoactivity of engineered Bi x O y Br z materials. Current studies have demonstrated that reducing the thickness of layered material can shorten the transport distance of photogenerated charge carriers [43], thus facilitating their migration and separation. Therefore, the self-adaptive surface modulation on Bi x O y Br z materials with atomic thickness is highly desirable to fully exploit their application potential. In addition, as a polar semiconductor material, Bi x O y Br z can drive photogenerated electrons and holes to the opposite sites under spontaneous polarization, external stress or electric field, thus effectively promoting charge separation [192–194]. Fine-tuning these external fields to synergistically couple with bulk/surface engineering may be an effective strategy to further boost the charge separation of Bi x O y Br z . From the perspective of fundamentals, a deeper understanding of the photophysical processes (e.g., charge transfer, energy band bending, and energy transfer) will help the design of a more efficient charge transfer ensemble. And this can be entrusted to the advanced characterization techniques including time-resolved ultrafast spectroscopy, in situ techniques, and theoretical calculations. (II) The aforementioned self-adaptive bulk/surface engineering strategies are mostly designed to enhance the photoactivity of Bi x O y Br z . However, photocorrosion is another concern for practical application [3,33]. It has been reported that Bi nanoparticles, Bi5+ and Br vacancies can be formed in Bi x O y Br z due to the photoreduction and photooxidation under light irradiation [118,119,195,196]. The formations of these new sites are indeed caused by dynamic surface reconstruction of Bi x O y Br z during the reaction, which will reduce the stability of catalysts, and limit their performance far below the theoretical maximum. To address the photocorrosion issue, in addition to enhancing the charge separation and reducing surface/bulk charge recombination, surface passivation layers (e.g., TiO2 and Al2O3) and cocatalyst (e.g., FeOOH/NiOOH and Pt) deposition [24,39], which can alleviate the surface-related limitations of Bi-based semiconductors [23], are desirable to be exploited on Bi x O y Br z photocatalyst. (III) In the respect of modulating bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z , the in-situ synthesis strategy has the advantages of simplicity and efficiency, but it also brings multiple deviations at the same time. For instance, heteroatom doping and exposed facets engineering usually result in morphological changes, while surface modification processes could generate multifarious defective sites simultaneously. These changes are often interacted to affect the photocatalytic performance, making it difficult to judge the specific character and function of each unit. Conversely, post-processing methods offer precise tuning and control, but tend to be time-consuming and high-cost. For example, UV irradiation typically produces OVs in the material with the help of a special device and is accompanied by high energy consumption. Therefore, in order to reasonably present the structure–property-activity relationships of the Bi x O y Br z photocatalyst, scholars are required to select the most suitable modulating method. Currently, the application of machine learning in materials design has become a new research direction with the booming development of computational science [197,198]. Machine learning and high-throughput screening allow integrated computational modeling with big data, which can be effectively used to predict and screen material properties, explore reaction mechanisms, and improve synthesis methods. Therefore, in order to achieve high efficiency and accuracy at a low cost, it is recommended to design and optimize our experimental measures based on first-principles calculations. (IV) Regarding the photocatalytic applications, Bi x O y Br z -based materials are mostly investigated in the field of pollutant removal, which is known as a downhill reaction process. This is reasonable since the thermodynamic driving force of pristine BiOBr is not suitable to induce reduction reactions due to the low reduction power. Although recent research on the typical uphill reactions based on Bi x O y Br z -derived materials such as photocatalytic H2 production, CO2 reduction, and N2 fixation have emerged, catalytic efficiency is still in its infancy. Moreover, as for photoredox driven organic reactions that require multiple oxidative quenching steps, the electrons shuttling from Bi x O y Br z to the organic substrates would be challenging but rate-limiting. Thus, to boost the photocatalytic efficiency and extend the application fields, precise design, and control of integrating different engineering strategies to synergistically regulate the electronic and surface structure of Bi x O y Br z -based materials play substantial roles in promoting the energetics and kinetics of the photocatalytic reactions. Doping or tuning the ratios of Bi, O, and Br is a powerful strategy to modulate the band gap structure of Bi x O y Br z . How to optimize the synergy effects between doping/atom ratio regulation and other surface engineering methods to guarantee good efficiency, ameliorated stability, and multifunctional photocatalytic applications still needs more extensive and in-depth investigations. (V) Last but not least, the photocatalytic applications of Bi x O y Br z -based materials are currently limited on a laboratory scale. In the face of large-scale applications, researchers are encouraged to explore novel and facile strategies beyond the traditional energy and time-consuming solvothermal/hydrothermal method, such as microwave-assisted synthesis, to achieve a large-scale synthesis of Bi x O y Br z -based materials with high production yield. To further maximize the catalytic efficiency, future work could focus on the intelligent combination of photocatalysis with other technologies such as thermal-catalytic and electrocatalytic techniques to enable the large-scale applications of Bi x O y Br z -based photocatalysts. In this regard, custom-made multifunctional reactors should be precisely designed, and how to avoid the potential secondary harms to the ecosystem and environment from the nanoscale photocatalysts need to be carefully considered. After addressing these challenges, Bi x O y Br z -based materials are expected to have a bright future in the photocatalytic field. coredata.dc:description: The bulk/surface states of semiconductor photocatalysts are imperative parameters to maneuver their performance by significantly affecting the key processes of photocatalysis including light absorption, separation of charge carrier, and surface site reaction. Recent years have witnessed the encouraging progress of self-adaptive bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z for photocatalytic applications spanning various fields. However, despite the maturity of current research, the interaction between the bulk/surface state and the performance of Bi x O y Br z has not yet been fully understood and highlighted. In this regard, a timely tutorial overview is quite urgent to summarize the most recent key progress and outline developing obstacles in this exciting area. Herein, the structural characteristics and fundamental principles of Bi x O y Br z for driving photocatalytic reaction as well as related key issues are firstly reviewed. Then, we for the first time summarized different self-adaptive engineering processes over Bi x O y Br z followed by a classification of the generation approaches towards diverse Bi x O y Br z materials. The features of different strategies, the up-to-date characterization techniques to detect bulk/surface states, and the effect of bulk/surface states on improving the photoactivity of Bi x O y Br z in expanded applications are further discussed. Finally, the present research status, challenges, and future research opportunities of self-adaptive bulk/surface engineered Bi x O y Br z are prospected. It is anticipated that this critical review can trigger deeper investigations and attract upcoming innovative ideas on the rational design of Bi x O y Br z -based photocatalysts.
